results.title: Before the rain = Pred dozhdot
results.creator_credit: Milcho Manchevski, Sam Taylor, Cedomir Kolar, Judy Counihan, Vardar Films, Noe Productions and AIM
results.headline_credit: Macedonia, The Former Yugoslav Republic Of, 1994
results.brief_description: Subtitled ‘A Tale in Three Parts’, Milcho Manchevski’s debut feature film tells three stories dealing with the ancestral ethnic rivalry eating at the heart and soul of the newly formed republic of Macedonia. The first tale follows the fate of young Orthodox monk Kiril (Gregoire Colin) as he attempts to shelter a young Albanian girl from the wrath of the local villagers, thus unleashing the full might of a long-standing ethnic feud onto the monastery. The second tale is set in London where Anne (Katrin Cartlidge) is considering leaving her husband to live with Aleksander (Rade Serbedzija), a world-weary war correspondent, who has just returned just from Bosnia. The last tale documents Aleksander’s road back to the Macedonian village of his youth. Tired of photographing war, Aleksander, finds his home on the brink, with tensions between Macedonian and Albanian villagers at an all time high. (Awards: Winner of the Best Film Prize at the 1994 Venice Film festival). Manchevski was at pains to explain at the time of release that his film was not a documentary on Macedonia or the Balkans, as the tension described in ‘Before the Rain’, could erupt anywhere, anytime. In Macedonian with English subtitles.

results.title: Native land
results.brief_description: The Ku Klux Klan brutally tar and feather three trade union supporters. Sharecroppers demanding a living wage are hunted down and killed by the local sheriff’s deputies. This film vividly re-enacts these and other actual events, and blends them with documentary footage and narration and songs by Paul Robeson into a call for a social revolution. Hurwitz lost possession of the film during the McCarthy trials. Attempts were even made by the US Government to have the original negatives destroyed - but the film survived, returning to circulation in 1974.

results.title: Our daily bread
results.brief_description: ‘Our Daily Bread’ forms part of Vidor’s ‘Back to the Land’ trilogy, which also includes ‘The Stranger Returns’ (1933) and ‘The Wedding Night’ (1935). In his book on filmmaking, Vidor claims that he was developing a style that would integrate a ‘dramatic entertaining storyline’ with the ‘realism and credibility of a Flaherty-type documentary’. This film represents the height of the process. It tells the story of a young couple, Mary and John Sims, who are forced by the Depression to accept ownership of a bankrupt farm. With the help of a local Swedish farmer, they turn the dusty tract of land into a blooming spread and gradually a co-operative community establishes itself, in which support is mutual and money is not needed. The irrigation set piece which provides the film’s climax is justly famous. In 1935, the film was distributed under the title ‘The Miracle of life’ according to AMPAS records. The film opens with an interview with King Vidor recorded by David Shepard in the 1980s. ‘Our Daily Bread’ is followed by 2 short films, anonymously produced by Irving Thalberg at MGM in support of the re-election of the conservative party at the Californian gubernatorial elections. Cast includes Karen Morley, Tom Keene, Barbara Pepper, Addison Richards and John Qualen.

results.title: Preston Sturges: the rise and fall of an American dreamer
results.brief_description: This is a survey of the career of writer-director Preston Sturges tracing the highs and lows of his life illuminated with clips from his films and extracts from interviews with Eddie Bracken, Betty Hutton, Joel McCrea, Paul Schrader, Andrew Sarris and others. Sturges is acknowledged as Hollywood’s first ironist whose satires of American mores skillfully outwitted the Hays code. Clips featured are from “The Great McGinty (1940)”, “Sullivan’s travels (1941), “The Miracle of Morgan’s Creek” (1944), “Hail the conquering hero” (1944), “The Beautiful blond from bashful bend” (1949), plus many more. Narrated by Fritz Weaver.

results.title: Journey of hope = Reise der Hoffnung = Umud'a yolculuk
results.creator_credit: Xavier Koller, Alfi Sinniger, Catpics and Condor Features
results.brief_description: The true story of a Turkish couples’s flight, with their young son, from the abject poverty and hardship of their mountain village in Turkey to the land of unimagined riches - Switzerland. Selling everything they have in the world to pay for their illegal passage, and leaving the rest of their children with relatives, the three unworldly travellers begin their journey. After initially being refused entry at the border, they and other refugees like them fall prey to a group of smugglers, who direct them to access Switzerland via an illegal and dangerous mountain pass. Despite murderous weather they are sent on their way, alone, their guides unwilling to brave the perils of the journey. Acted, photographed and edited with impeccable restraint, this is a haunting, dignified and inspiring film. Cast includes: Necmettin Cobanoglu, Nur Surer and Emin Sivas. In German and Turkish with English subtitles. Winner of Academy Award for Best Foreign Film 1990 and Golden Leopard Award, Locarno Film Festival.

results.title: Innocence unprotected = Nevinost bez zastite
results.creator_credit: Dusan Makavejev, Bosko Savic and Avala Film
results.brief_description: The first all-Serbian talkie feature rescued from oblivion by Makavejev was made in 1942 during the Nazi Occupation, a naive melodrama in which a strong man (played by the filmmaker, a real life strong man-cum-Houdini type) rescues the heroine from a lecher and a wicked stepmother. It was banned by the Occupation government for attracting local audiences away from more sophisticated German fare, then denounced after the war for being German-inspired. Makavejev colour tinted the footage to highlight its folk charm. Through a dialectical approach to montage he provides an ironic commentary on the themes of innocence and time by intercutting the fictional footage, interviews with members of the original production and wartime newsreels. In Serbo-Croatian with English subtitles. Cast includes Ivanka Vukasovic, Dragoljub Gojkovic Beli and Miodrag Petrovic Sarlo. Note: Original film directed by Dragolyub Aleksic.

results.title: The Bat whispers [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Roland West and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: An arch-criminal known as ‘The Bat’ who taunts police officers by providing clues about his upcoming crimes, terrorises the occupants of an isolated mansion during a raging thunderstorm. Though highly formulaic with all the narrative and iconographic cliches of the melodramatic haunted house genre such as rooms concealed behind swiveling fireplaces, subplots revolving around fragments of obscure treasure maps, shots, screams and faulty electric lighting, the film distinguishes itself through a succession of astonishing visual sequences. Director Roland West specially designed and constructed equipment and models that allowed the camera to exuberantly swoop, glide and zoom through space, hurtle down corridors and lurch from the tops of buildings. The stylised high-contrast expressionistic lighting is evocative of the German silent cinema which the director revered. One of the first films to be shot in widescreen (65mm ‘Magnifilm’), this version has been restored by the UCLA film archive. Nine years after the film’s release, the memory of its caped master-criminal inspired young comic-book artist Bob Kane to create a new superhero: Batman.

results.title: Martin Scorsese directs
results.creator_credit: Steven Fischer, Joel Sucher and Pacific Street Film Projects
results.brief_description: This documentary visits the set, the editing rooms and the mixing studios during the production of “Goodfellas”. It also includes many clips from his body of work including “Mean Streets”, “Raging Bull”, “New York, New York” and “The Last Temptation of Christ”, as well as interviews with the director, his family, friends and colleagues from the film world such as Steven Spielberg, Robert De Niro, Harvey Keitel, Joe Pesci, and George Lucas.

results.title: Tales of the Taira Clan = Shin heiki monogatari
results.creator_credit: Kenji Mizoguchi, Masaichi Nagata and Daiei Motion Picture Company
results.brief_description: Set in twelfth-century Japan against a rich social and political background, this is an epic tale of power struggles, family drama, and human frailty. Mizoguchi lavished everything - sumptuous colour, elaborate sets and costumes - on this gripping drama, making his penultimate film - only one of two films he made in colour - a masterpiece. In Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: Ordet = The Word
results.creator_credit: Carl Theodor Dreyer and Palladium Films
results.brief_description: Ordet = (The Word) is film that explores the polarities of faith and the journey from hypocrisy to true faith. In a remote village in Denmark, two families feud as a result of opposing religious faiths and their religious intolerance. Old Borgen’s family is further tested when his son, Johannes is driven mad by reading Kierkegarde and believes he is the risen Christ. Dreyer simply explores the notion of faith by illustrating the inadequacies of doctrines when pitted against people with profound needs. True faith is explored when the family turn in desperation to each other as Inger, the wife of Borgen’s older son Mikkel and light of the family unexpectedly dies. Dreyer reduces the sound in the film in a way that creates a meditative atmosphere heightening its religious theme. In Danish with English subtitles.
